holidays.name: National Static Electricity Day
holidays.description: A day to celebrate the fascinating phenomenon of static electricity‚Äîthe tiny shocks and crackles you feel from rubbing certain materials!
holidays.origin: Originating from scientific observations of static charges, this unofficial day encourages experiments with static electricity and awareness of its quirky effects.
holidays.funFact: Did you know that the first electric bell, invented in 1831, operated using principles of static electricity?

holidays.name: Play God Day
holidays.description: This delightfully unusual holiday invites you to imagine being an all-powerful deity, making big decisions about the universe or simply having fun with your god-like powers in games or storytelling.
holidays.origin: Though not officially recognized, it emerged from creative communities craving a playful escape into omnipotence.
holidays.funFact: Many classic video games and board games, like 'SimCity' and 'Black & White', let players 'play God' by controlling worlds and destinies.

holidays.name: National Apricot Day
holidays.description: Celebrate the sweet, golden apricot, a fruit loved for its delicious flavor and nutritional benefits.
holidays.origin: This food holiday encourages enjoying apricots fresh, dried, or in recipes to start the year with a tasty boost.
holidays.funFact: Apricots have been grown for thousands of years and were cherished by ancient Romans, who called them 'praecocia', meaning 'early ripening'.

holidays.name: Identify Your Vices Day
holidays.description: A quirky introspective day that encourages people to honestly identify their little habits and vices, whether it's binge-watching TV, snacking late at night, or any other guilty pleasure.
holidays.origin: An unofficial, humorous day aimed at helping people laugh at themselves and perhaps consider healthier choices.
holidays.funFact: Many world-famous artists and writers turned their 'vices' into creative fuel rather than sources of guilt.
